close_symbols: MHD_AccessHandlerCallback (callback parameter contracts for method, url, version)
explanation:
To decide if ahc_echo violates the <string.h> bounds rule we must be able to prove that every call into string.h (strcmp, strlen, memcmp) cannot read past the end of the referenced objects. The following symbols are required and why:

1) struct MHD_BasicAuthInfo
   - Needed to know the types and semantics of auth_info->username, auth_info->username_len, auth_info->password, auth_info->password_len. The code calls memcmp(auth_info->username, "Aladdin", auth_info->username_len) and memcmp(auth_info->password, "open sesame", auth_info->password_len) without an explicit NULL-check on username. We must know whether the implementation guarantees that username (and password) pointers are non-NULL when the corresponding length is non-zero and that the buffer pointed-to is at least username_len/password_len bytes long.

2) MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3
   - The safety of the memcmp/strlen checks depends on the contract of this function: when it returns non-NULL, how it populates the MHD_BasicAuthInfo fields, whether it can return an auth_info with username==NULL but username_len != 0 (or vice versa), and whether username/password are owned by the caller or valid until MHD_free is called. We must know these invariants to ensure memcmp and the length comparisons cannot dereference or read out-of-bounds.

3) MHD_AccessHandlerCallback (callback parameter contracts for method, url, version)
   - The code calls strcmp(method, "GET") and otherwise applies strlen on string literals or other parameters. We need the API contract for the callback parameters (especially 'method') to be sure 'method' is a NUL-terminated C string (so strcmp is well-defined). If the library only supplies length-delimited buffers for these parameters, strcmp could read past the buffer.

4) DENIED
   - The code calls strlen(DENIED) and passes DENIED to response creation. We must know that DENIED is a properly NUL-terminated array or string literal (or otherwise has a well-defined length) so strlen(DENIED) does not read out-of-bounds.

5) PAGE
   - Same reason as DENIED: strlen(PAGE) is invoked; PAGE must be a valid NUL-terminated string or otherwise have a documented accessible length.

(Notes: The standard functions strcmp/strlen/memcmp themselves are the subject of the rule but their semantics are standard; the missing pieces are the object layouts and API contracts above. With the definitions/contracts above one can show whether the memcmp and strlen/strcmp calls are guaranteed to only access bytes within the referenced objects.)
